title: Vectors in one dimension - velocity comparison

content.question: Figure A and Figure B both show two velocity vectors. Let <math alttext="vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> and <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> be the vector sums of the velocity vectors in Figure A and Figure B, respectively. Are the speed and the velocity of <math alttext="vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> the same as the speed and velocity of <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>?

choices.label: Yes, because both vectors have the same magnitude.
Yes, because both vectors point in the same direction.

No, because <math alttext="vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> has a magnitude of <math alttext="positive 5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> and <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> has a magnitude of <math alttext="negative 5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>.
No, because the vectors are in opposite directions, which means the velocities are different.

content.answer: No, because the vectors are in opposite directions, which means the velocities are different.
